events.name: #DataDrivenSG Hackathon Singapore - Day 1: Business Track
events.description: This is day 1 of a 3-day event hosted by Keboola and Coding Girls and is being announced on behalf of our community member. The business track and hackathon are aimed at professionals, for entry-level focus please refer to Data Girls workshop on day 3. Title: #DataDrivenSG Business Track Singapore Abstract:Calling all data analysts, scientists, nerds and geeks!We are inviting you to our inaugural #DatadrivenSG hackathon, where you will, over the course of one and a half days, have a chance to play with the newest and coolest tools on real world data and help to solve real business problems. — Networking event for both business people and hackathon participants — Partner introductions — Introductions of technology available at the Hackathon — Keynotes (1-3 speakers, tbc.) Agenda:4:00PM to 4:15PM - Event Introduction4:15PM to 4:45PM - Partners Introduction4:45PM to 5:30PM - Keynote Speeches5:30PM to 7:00PM - Technology introductions by individual vendors and partners7:00PM to 8:00PM - Networking *For huge interest, we are going to keep accepting RSVPs, but will send out questionaires in next few days to qualify participants, to make sure they are good fit for the event and everyone participating has fun.* Learn more about the #DataDriven Hackathon Singapore here: http://www.datadriven.sg/hackathon Register for business track and hackathon at: https://www.eventbrite.com.au/e/datadrivensg-hackathon-singapore-by-keboola-and-codinggirls-tickets-27768828313 We are promoting this event because it aligns with our group interests. For deeper engagement with Apache Apex - follow ApacheApex, presentations, recordings, download (community, sandbox), Apache Apex releases, docs
events.location: The Hangar by NUS Enterprise, 21 Heng Mui Keng Terrace, Singapore
events.group_name: Apache Apex Next Gen Native Hadoop Big Data, Singapore

events.name: TGIFHacks #56 - Design for hackers
events.description:
We know you can crack the tech, but do other humans like how it looks and works? 

This workshop helps hackers and coders build products which are beautifully designed and compelling to use. We’ll be going through the fundamental principles of graphic design and interaction design, and how they come together in the things that matter to you- hackathon projects, websites, resumes etc. 

This is a workshop for non-designers to understand the visual language that fuels all great design. Participants will not be asked to design or code on the spot- this is not a CSS or Photoshop tutorial.
events.location: The Nest Theatre @ Innovation Centre, , Singapore 63

events.name: Friday Hacks #122: NUSMods v3.0 & Open Source
events.description:
This week is about some of the things our very own NUS students have been working on. We also have members from the NUSMods team talking about the latest things they’ve been doing to improve the timetable builder. See you there!

Been working on something cool and want to speak about it at Friday Hacks? Drop us an email at coreteam@nushackers.org.

Date/Time: Friday, October 21 at 6:30pm 
Venue: SR3, Town Plaza, University Town 
Free pizza is served before the talks. 

Talk 1: NUSMods v3.0 and Modify.sg - Building the next-gen timetable

Talk Description:

The team behind NUSMods has jumped on the bandwagon of JavaScript fatigue with an overhauled front end codebase. NUSMods 3.0 brings a whole new consideration for user experience and technical performance by utilizing the latest cutting edge JavaScript libraries. Join us as we talk about the new features and improvements, the insights and process behind the multiple attempts at building a next-generation module management and timetabling interface.

Speaker Profile

Li Kai is a Year 2 student at NUS who likes helping people by building useful stuff.

Yang Shun is an alumnus who helped build NUSMods 2.0, started NUSWhispers and is currently working at Grab as an Internal Tools Engineer.

Talk 2: Open Source

Talk Description:

Jethro will be talking about how he got into open-source, what he learnt, why one should do it, and how one could get started.

Speaker Profile

Jethro is a Year 1 NUS CS student who’s trying to turn his hobby into his livelihood. In his free time, he organises meetups for Emacs, and works on open-source projects.
events.location: SR3, Town Plaza, University Town, NUS, , Singapore

events.name: Future Fridays: The Medium is the Message?
events.description:
Often, when we reach out to the public to raise awareness of an issue, or to recruit volunteers, we concentrate on getting as many eyeballs as possible. What goes into making a campaign viral? Are the stories we are telling respectful of the issues that we want to work on, and empowering to everyone involved? In this session, we will experiment with some approaches to build up part of our outreach toolkit.

==

October is all about the Future of Giving! Sustainable Living Lab and (these)abilities will be examining the trends affecting what motivates volunteers, experimenting with different messages to engage them and exploring how cutting edge technologies can help create strong volunteer relationships. Whether you are a volunteer, a volunteer manager or simply curious, you can’t miss this! At the end of this series, we hope that you will understand and be inspired by the principles behind inclusive design. We also hope that whether you are a volunteer or a volunteer manager you will walk away with a toolkit that will help you to manage volunteer relationships better.

Write us at chewlin.kay@sl2square.org if you are joining us!
events.location: Sustainable Living Lab (SL2), 1 Tampines Street 73, Singapore 528704
